articles.headline: Kamala Harris Is Biden’s Choice for Vice President
articles.snippet: A former rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, she will be the first woman of color to be nominated for national office by a major political party.
articles.abstract: A former rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, she will be the first woman of color to be nominated for national office by a major political party.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: In Kamala Harris, a Choice at Once Safe and Energizing
articles.snippet: Her selection as Joe Biden’s running mate was conventional by some political standards. But it was historic most of all, and especially sweet for many Black women.
articles.abstract: Her selection as Joe Biden’s running mate was conventional by some political standards. But it was historic most of all, and especially sweet for many Black women.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In naming Kamala Harris as his running mate, Joseph R. Biden Jr. made a groundbreaking decision, picking a woman of color to be vice president and, possibly, a successor in the White House someday. Yet in some ways, Mr. Biden made a conventional choice: elevating a senator who brings generational and coastal balance to the Democratic ticket and shares his center-left politics at a time of progressive change in the party.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: Kamala Harris, a Political Fighter Shaped by Life in Two Worlds
articles.snippet: She grew up around Berkeley activists but came to believe working from inside the system had greater power to effect change.
articles.abstract: She grew up around Berkeley activists but came to believe working from inside the system had greater power to effect change.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our profile of Kamala Harris, the first woman elected U.S. vice president.]
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Luxury Homes Tie Chinese Communist Elite to Hong Kong’s Fate
articles.snippet: Three top leaders of China’s Communist Party have relatives who own assets in Hong Kong, including more than $51 million in luxury real estate, a New York Times investigation shows.
articles.abstract: Three top leaders of China’s Communist Party have relatives who own assets in Hong Kong, including more than $51 million in luxury real estate, a New York Times investigation shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Li Qianxin, the elder daughter of the Chinese Communist Party’s No. 3 leader, has quietly crafted a life in Hong Kong that traverses the city’s financial elite and the secretive world of Chinese politics.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: QAnon Followers Are Hijacking the #SaveTheChildren Movement
articles.snippet: Fans of the pro-Trump conspiracy theory are clogging anti-trafficking hotlines, infiltrating Facebook groups and raising false fears about child exploitation.
articles.abstract: Fans of the pro-Trump conspiracy theory are clogging anti-trafficking hotlines, infiltrating Facebook groups and raising false fears about child exploitation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Recently, an acquaintance posted a photo on her Instagram story showing a map of the United States, filled with bright red dots.

articles.headline: 1,193 Quarantined for Covid. Is This a Successful School Reopening?
articles.snippet: A suburban Atlanta county opened its schools amid controversy and a growing case count, previewing a difficult national back-to-school season.
articles.abstract: A suburban Atlanta county opened its schools amid controversy and a growing case count, previewing a difficult national back-to-school season.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANTON, Ga. — The first letter went out on Aug. 4, one day after students in the Cherokee County School District returned to their classrooms for the first time since the eruption of the coronavirus pandemic.

articles.headline: Advisers Consider Whether Trump Can Cut Taxes Without Congress
articles.snippet: Trump’s lawyers and economic advisers have studied how far they could stretch executive authority to set tax policy, though the legality of any cuts is dubious.
articles.abstract: Trump’s lawyers and economic advisers have studied how far they could stretch executive authority to set tax policy, though the legality of any cuts is dubious.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials have explored whether President Trump has the power to sidestep Congress and unilaterally cut a broad swath of taxes as the president looks for ways to inject fuel into a slumping economy, according to a senior administration official.
